translated: YogÄcÄrabhÅ«mi ÅšÄstra, fascicle 65
Expounded by Maitreya Bodhisattva
Translated by Tripiá¹­aka Master Xuanzang on imperial command
Among the Ascertainment Chapter, the stage of wisdom accomplished through contemplation, part 1. Thus far, the discernment of the stage accomplished through hearing has been explained.
I will now explain the discernment of the stage accomplished through contemplation.
Discussion.
Second, the inconceivable of existence and non-existence.
Third, the inconceivable of cause and effect.
Fourth, the inconceivable of the vehicle.
As for the inconceivable of phenomena,
in brief, it is based on six phenomena.
Namely, the phenomena of the aggregates up to the phenomena of the faculties.
As for the inconceivable of existence and non-existence,
it is as explained in the Basic Section.
As for the inconceivable of cause and effect,
it is as explained in the stage with investigation and analysis.
As for the inconceivable of the vehicle,
it is as explained in the stages of the Å›rÄvaka, pratyekabuddha, and bodhisattva.
Furthermore, there are roughly two kinds of inconceivability.
Namely, the inconceivability of evil thoughts and the inconceivability of good thoughts.
As for the inconceivability of evil thoughts,
it is as explained in the Basic Section.
If based on the black category,
It means that there is one who does not avoid ignorance, does not think as he should, and yet gives rise to thought.
Good thought means
The opposite of this should be known.
Just as bad thought and good thought, so tooğŸ”½Not drawn by what is not Dharma, drawn by what is Dharma.
Not drawn by what is not Vinaya, drawn by what is Vinaya.
Not noble, noble.
Unwholesome, wholesome.
Not to be cultivated, to be cultivated.
Not good, good.
Black, white.
Drawing no benefit, drawing benefit.
Inferior, sublime.
Guilty, guiltless.
To be shunned, not to be shunned, and so on.
One should know it is also like this.
Furthermore, as the World-Honored One said,
The noble disciples have knowledge of what exists as existing,
And knowledge of what does not exist as not existing.
What, in this case, is existence?
What is non-existence?
In brief, existence should be known by two characteristics.
What are the two?
First, if it has already arisen, it is present.
should be understood as existent.
Second, if it is a real entity, because of its function, meaning, and perfect accomplishment,
it should be understood as existent.
How should it be understood?
In brief, the characteristics of real existence and provisional existence are as follows.
Namely, if dharmas
do not depend on others and do not rely on others to establish their own characteristics,
it should be understood that in brief this is the characteristic of real existence.
If there are dharmas
that depend on others and rely on others to establish their own characteristics,
it should be understood that in brief this is the characteristic of provisional existence.
It is not real existence.
Namely, using the conceptualized events of the aggregates such as form as the basis,
one establishes the existence of a self, sentient beings, and so forth.
And so on, explaining in detail.
Herein, the conceptualized events of the aggregates such as form are real existence.
The self, sentient beings, life, birth, and the one who takes rebirth and so forth are not real existence.
They are only provisionally existent.
Just as using the conceptualized events of the aggregates such as form,
the self and so forth are provisionally established in this way.
It is precisely with regard to the conceptual things such as form, etc.,
that form, etc. are provisionally established.
Moreover, with regard to the conceptual things such as form, smell, taste, and touch,
food, drink, vehicles, vessels, clothing, various ornaments, houses, armies, forests, etc. are provisionally established.
Moreover, with regard to the conceptual things of conditioned dharmas,
birth, old age, duration, impermanence, seeds,ğŸ”½the life faculty, the similarity of species,
the nature of being an ordinary person,
coalescence, non-coalescence, evolution, definite difference, association, speed, sequence, time, place, and number are provisionally established.
Moreover, it is only by relying on the non-transformation of various forms that
space, which is a non-conditioned dharma, is provisionally established.
Moreover, it is only by relying on the non-transformation of names in the middle that
the attainment of non-perception, the attainment of cessation, etc. are provisionally established.
In the reasoning of cause and effect,
how can one ascertain with certainty that the self does not really exist?
The answer is: because it cannot be apprehended and because it cannot be seen.
How is it unapprehendable?
Whether internal, external, or in between the two,
whether apart from the aggregates,
it cannot be apprehended at all.
Why is it invisible?
It is like the real existence of the eyes and other faculties,
each having a visible function.
The function of the self conceived in this way is completely invisible.
In this way, because its own characteristics cannot be apprehended,
and because its separate function is invisible,
it should be known that the self conceived in this way does not really exist.
Question: If this self cannot be apprehended at all, whether internally, externally, or in between, and also cannot be seen,
why do the renunciant non-Buddhists also apprehend it and also see it?
For this reason, they love to display and establish its real existence.
Answer: They do not apprehend it or see it.
But because they rely on the view of self and the conceit of self,
they give rise to wrong discrimination and wrong conceptualization, not in accordance with right reason.
They love to display and establish it as existent.
How do we know that the self does not really exist, and therefore does not presently exist?
It cannot be obtained and also cannot be seen.
Those who consider the self to be truly existent do not go beyond four types.
First, considering the self to be the aggregates.
Second, considering the self to be different from the aggregates, abiding within the aggregates.
Third, considering the self to be neither the aggregates nor different from the aggregates,
not abiding within the aggregates but abiding in something different from the aggregates, apart from the aggregates.
Fourth, considering the self to be neither the aggregates nor different from the aggregates,
not abiding within the aggregates nor abiding in something different from the aggregates, apart from the aggregates.
But without the aggregates.
All aggregate phenomena are not mutually corresponding.
Those who rely on the self to discriminate and consider it to exist,
are all included in these four types of considerations.
Apart from this, there is no more or less.
In this way, all the true natures of the self are unreasonable.
Why is it so?
If it is considered that the self is the aggregates and not different from the aggregates,
Then this self is only provisionally established based on the aggregates.
This fault will naturally arise.
Why is it so?
The aggregates are impermanent.
Each corresponds with its own characteristics.
Because the self is identical to them, it is not permanent, not unitary, and not a truly existent nature.
Therefore, this view is not in accordance with reason.
If one views the self as different from the aggregates,
this conceived self
is either impermanent or permanent.
If it is impermanent,
then the conceived self arises and ceases differently in each moment.
It dies in one place and is reborn in another.
One acts and another experiences.
This fault will naturally arise.
Moreover, if there is a self separate from the aggregates,
whether internally, externally, or in between the two,
birth and cessation cannot be apprehended at all.
Therefore, this view is not in accordance with reason.
If the self is permanent,
its characteristic is unchanging.
If this conceived self is unchanging,
Both reasons for change are unreasonable.
It is neither in the future nor in the present life.
If there is no change in the self in the future,
then there should be no birth, no aging, no sickness, no death, and no harm.
One should also not be a god at one time and a human at another time.
Or be an animal, or a ghost,
or sometimes be a hell being.
In the present life, if the self does not change,
then one should have no pleasure or pain, no love or hatred, and no delusion towards various desirable and undesirable objects.
In brief, one should not be changed by pleasure, pain, etc.
One should not be changed by any of the afflictions such as greed, or by the secondary afflictions.
Thus, because there is no change in the self in the future or in the present life,
one should not be benefited by pleasure.
One should also not be defiled by the afflictions that belong to it.
One should not, on this account, practice Dharma or non-Dharma.
It should not be harmed by suffering.
It should also not be defiled by the afflictions that belong to it.
It should not, on this account, practice what is Dharma or what is not Dharma.
This self is like this.
In the present world, because it is not associated with Dharma or non-Dharma,
in the future world, because there is no cause or condition for a body that is either loved or not loved,
it should not be born.
For this reason, you should not conceive of this permanent self.
Because of the transformation of the separate inner body,
in the future world, there are various transformations such as birth, old age, and death.
In this way, this self would not have a separate existence.
When the inner body is born, grows old, becomes ill, dies, and so forth, at times of happiness, at times of suffering, and at times of defilement,
it should be eternally liberated and pure.
Therefore, this conception is not reasonable.
Furthermore, if one conceives of a self that is different from the aggregates, abiding apart from the aggregates, and existing apart from the aggregates,
the dharmas conceived by them are far removed from the aggregates.
The self-characteristics of existence cannot be obtained.
How much less can it be established as the self of a person.
It is like saying, I clearly know that the daughter of a stone woman has an empty flower garland tied on top of her head.
You should know that this view is also like this.
Therefore, this view is not in accord with reason.
Furthermore, if one views the existence of a self, because it is not in accord with all the dharmas of the aggregates, it does not have the aggregates.
This viewed self, if it does not have the aggregates, then it has no form.
It is not in accord with the body.
It is also not in accord with the various feelings such as suffering and happiness.
It is also not in accord with the various distinctions of thoughts.
It is also not in accord with the thoughts of good, bad, and neutral.
It is also not in accord with the discriminating mind that experiences objects such as form.
In this way, this self would have no basis, no feelings, no thoughts, no considerations, and also no discrimination.
In this case, this self would not require effort.
It would be ultimately liberated and undefiled.
Therefore, this view is not reasonable.
Moreover, all [views] depend on the self.
Because the self that is falsely imagined is not established,
it should be known that the self, etc., are only provisionally established in the aggregates.
They are not real entities.
Because the self does not exist, only the aggregates exist.
Therefore, the principles of all defilement and purification are all accomplished.
That is to say, because there are internal and external sense bases,
in the present life, the contact of ignorance arises.
Because of this, there is beneficial and harmful feeling that arises in the body.
Because of this as a condition, love and existence, etc., that cause union and separation, arise.
All the afflictions and secondary afflictions arise based on this.
For this meaning, pure and impure karma can arise and be obtained.
In this way, because afflictions and karma arise,
in the future, the arising of birth, old age, death, and all other suffering dharmas can all arise.
In this way, moreover, because there is no real self in the impermanent aggregates,
The principles of defilement are all accomplished.
Moreover, due to the causes and conditions of the other's sound and correct contemplation within,
one distances oneself from ignorance and gives rise to illumination.
Due to non-delusion, one realizes that all feelings are suffering.
Because of this, one is able to sever all craving and attachment towards feelings.
And one severs all afflictions and secondary afflictions that rely on this.
Because of this, one is no longer able to give rise to pure or impure karma that can lead to future existence.
In this way, due to the severance of karma and afflictions,
all future existence, birth, and so forth, will never arise again.
In this way, since there is only the aggregates and no self,
the principles of all defilement and purity are accomplished.
Next, in this context, all sentient beings are provisionally established.
Namely, those without feet, with two feet, with four feet, and with many feet.
Those with form, without form, with thought, without thought, neither thought nor non-thought, and sentient beings in the sphere of neither perception nor non-perception.
One should know that there are these nine kinds of sentient beings.
It is established by three kinds of causes and conditions.
It comprehensively includes all kinds of sentient beings.
Namely, based on the differences in the movement of the body that comes and goes,
Sentient beings are established from those without feet up to those with many feet.
Based on the differences in the body,
Sentient beings with form and without form are established.
Based on the differences in the mind,
Sentient beings with thought, without thought, and neither thought nor non-thought are established.
Furthermore, there are non-Buddhist practitioners who are free from attachments.
They say like this:
All trees and so forth are all alive.
Seeing that they are the same as the inner life-bearing dharmas,
They increase and grow together.
One should tell them:
What do you want?
Is the growth of trees and so forth caused by life,
Or is there another cause of growth?
If they only use life as the cause,
As long as they have not given up their life,
It would not make sense for them to have no growth at one time.
If there is another cause of growth,
Even if they have no life,
It is unreasonable because they can also grow by their own causes and conditions.
Moreover, you should tell them:
What do you think?
Do things without life not grow?
Is it said to have a cause or to have no cause?
If it is said to have a cause,
because the cause and conditions cannot be obtained,
it is unreasonable.ğŸ”½If it is said to have no cause,
if it must be so without a cause,
it is unreasonable.
Moreover, you should tell them:
What do you think?ğŸ”½Are things like trees and other things
completely similar to things with life?
Or are they not completely similar?
If you say they are completely similar,
the roots and lower parts of things like trees enter the ground and grow upwards,
but they cannot naturally move their bodies,
and although they are spoken to, they do not respond.
It has never been seen that they turn to good or evil karma,
and when their branches and trunks are cut, they grow again elsewhere.
This is unreasonable.
If you say they are not entirely similar,
then it is because of similarity that there can be life.
Because of dissimilarity, there should be no life.
This is unreasonable.
In this way, there is the presence or absence of other causes for growth.
Because of presence, things without life do not grow.
The presence or absence of causes is explained.
Because of presence, similarity, and non-similarity,
this imagined view is unreasonable.
Why is it known that form, smell, taste, and touch are thus in the establishment of distinctions?
The things of thought such as food, vehicles, containers, clothing, and ornaments are all provisional existences.
The answer is because of the things of thought.
In some cases, in a collection of things of form, etc., they arise.
In some cases, in a collection of things of form, etc., they do not arise.
If in a collection of things of form, etc., the thought of food arises,
then in that place, the thought of drink, etc., does not arise.
If in a collection of things of form, etc., the thought of a vehicle arises,
It is not that the perception of clothes and so forth arises in relation to them.
In this way, it is explained in detail for the rest.
One should know that it is the same for other conceptual thoughts, whether they arise or not.
All thoughts of form, smell, taste, and touch,
are without distinction in all thoughts of things such as food and drink, vehicles, jars and vases, clothing, ornaments, and so forth.
They arise.
Therefore one should know that
food and drink, vehicles, jars and vases, clothing, ornaments, and so forth,
are all nominally existent.
Form, smell, taste, and touch are substantially existent.
Moreover, nominally existent things are established based on existent dharmas.
They are not one, but many, of various kinds.
It should be known that in brief there are two kinds:
First, based on a single aggregate;
Second, based on not a single aggregate.
Each separately, food and drink, vehicles, clothing, ornaments, and so forth,
are called based on a single aggregate.
Various painted works, carved works, and so forth, houses, palaces, armies, forests, and so forth,
It is called not a single aggregate.
Next, what are the form dharmas?
In brief, there are ten forms.
And the form included in the dharma realm.
Because those forms possess the characteristics of form.
By this matter, it is said again about this matter.
Therefore, it is called the form dharmas.
These form dharmas are established by five kinds of distinctions.
What are the five?
First, by substance.
Second, by intrinsic characteristic.
Third, by common characteristic.
Fourth, by realm.
Fifth, by function.
Among them, all that exists as form,
all of that is either the four great elements,
or is derived from the four great elements.
It should be known that this is the brief inclusion of form substances.
Apart from this, there is neither more nor less.
The intrinsic characteristics of form are of three kinds.ğŸ”½First, pure form.
Second, form grasped by the pure [mind].
Third, form grasped by the mind.
It is the five pure forms that are the basis for the five consciousnesses made of the four great elements.
It is called pure form.
The five objects such as form are the objects of the pure forms.
It is called the form that is taken as object by the pure [consciousness].
If the pure forms are together with consciousness and have the same object as the consciousness,
they are called similar.
If the pure forms are apart from consciousness and continue in a series of the same kind before and after,
they are called the forms that are similar to that [consciousness].
The forms that are images that are the objects of samÄdhi,
are called the forms that are taken as objects by the mind.
The general characteristics of forms are also of three kinds.
It is said that all forms, in terms of their spatial location and individual establishment,
can be spoken of in terms of their spatial distinctions.
This is called the first general characteristic.
Moreover, all forms, whether pure
or impure, increasing or decreasing,
should be known as the second general characteristic.
Moreover, all these forms, when touched, are immediately destroyed.
Or by hands, feet, clods, knives, sticks, etc.
Or by being touched by cold, heat, hunger, thirst, mosquitoes, gadflies, wind, sun, snakes, scorpions, and other contacts, it is immediately destroyed.
One should know that this is called the third common characteristic.
If it is produced by the karma of craving for form in the stage of concentration,
It is called the form of the form realm.
If it is produced by the karma of craving for form in the indeterminate stage,
It is called the form of the desire realm.
Thus, these forms are roughly of two kinds due to the distinction of realms.
There is no such form in the formless realm.
Moreover, the common characteristics of forms mentioned above,
Which are destroyed when touched by contact,
Such common characteristics are not all-pervasive.
Except for the gods in the desire realm, they are present everywhere else.
The forms in the desire realm of the gods
Only have the destruction of being touched by hands, feet, clods, knives, sticks, etc.
There is no destruction by the contact of cold, heat, hunger, thirst, etc.
Because in that heaven, all the necessary things such as food and drink are produced according to one's desires and then accomplished.
Therefore, although there is hunger and thirst there, it does not cause harm.
The form in the form realm is not damaged by the touch of hands, feet, clods, swords, sticks, etc.
It is also not damaged by other touches.
If there is good, bad, or indeterminate bodily action and verbal action,
this is called action form.
This should be known as the distinction of form and action.
The formless dharmas are also established by five aspects.
The opposite of this should be known.
Furthermore, the various aggregates are established in brief by two kinds of form aggregates.
One is the aggregate of great elements that are not shared.ğŸ”½The other is the aggregate of great elements that are not not shared.
The aggregate of great elements that are not shared means
that in this case, only one kind of great element can be obtained.
The aggregate of great elements that are not not shared means
that in this case, there are two great elements or many kinds of great elements that can be obtained.
Moreover, in a collection of unique primary elements,
the primary elements above the atoms are combined.
It should be understood that only then do they have mutual interpenetration and inseparability.
There is no primary element color in a single place that is not inseparable from all primary elements.
In a collection of primary elements that is not unique, the primary element atoms
are like the derivative form with the other primary elements.
It should be understood that there are also those that occupy the same place and are inseparable.
However, those primary elements are not derivative form.
Because they do not revolve in mutual dependence,
each has the ability to occupy a separate place.
Moreover, those that occupy the same place
refer to the primary elements and derivative form dwelling in the same place.
It is like placing a box with blue, yellow, red, and white luminous jewels, whose various lights are mutually inseparable.
Those that are interpenetrating and inseparable
should be understood using the same analogies as before.
Moreover, if there is a collection, such as sesame seeds, etc., or fine sand, etc.,
It is included in various resins, honey, and sugar, etc.
One should know that this is not non-separation in one place.ğŸ”½It is also not non-separation in the sense of being mixed together.
It is simply non-separation in the sense of being combined.
Many accumulations are not the characteristic of a single accumulation.
One should know that the remaining [aggregates] are the characteristic of a single accumulation.
Moreover, non-separation in the sense of being mixed together.
One should know that it is based on non-separation in one place.
If this is not so, it would not be reasonable.
Next, the distinction of visible phenomena is established by five aspects.
What are the five?
Namely, because of apparent color.ğŸ”½Because of shape.
Because of indicative form.ğŸ”½Because of being the object of the eye.
Because of being the object of visual consciousness.
The distinction of invisible phenomena is also established by five aspects.
One should understand its characteristics as being the opposite of the above.
Next, the distinction of obstructed phenomena is established by five aspects.
What are the five?
First, because they are established in separate places.
Second, it is because it can obstruct the activities of coming and going in other color aggregates.
Third, it is because it is destroyed when touched by hands, feet, clods, sticks, or weapons.
Fourth, it is because all of it is grasped by pure form.
Fifth, it is because all of it is the object of the consciousness that relies on pure form.
The distinction of the dharmas that are unimpeded should also be established by means of these five characteristics.
You should understand their characteristics as being the opposite of the above.
Moreover, by means of these five characteristics, you should understand the distinction of the dharmas that are invisible and unimpeded.
What are the five?
First, the cause.
Second, the location.
Third, the manifestation.
Fourth, the absence of change.
Fifth, the object.
That is to say, the resolve of form associated with the samÄdhi of those who possess authority.
This should be known as the cause for the arising of invisible and unimpeded form.
Once it has arisen, its location can be obtained.
Therefore, it is called form.
Although it is not associated with the intrinsic characteristics of the ten material sense bases,
it can appear similar to them in its own nature.
It can accommodate the activities of coming and going, etc., in other material aggregates, and does not obstruct their existence.
Moreover, not all pure form and the consciousness that depends on it
is the perceived object.
It is also not the object of perception.
Therefore it is said to be invisible and unimpeded.
The touch of hands and feet cannot destroy it.
Therefore it is said to be unchanging.
Also, the fundamental concentration is called the samÄdhi of great power.
This form is its object, not that of others.
For example, not all minds can transform.
Only those minds with great power can accomplish it.
This is also like that.
Only a mind with great power and extreme stillness can
use that as a condition to give rise to this invisible and unimpeded form.
This is like transformed form, which is also not the object-field of a mind with great majestic virtue or an undetermined mind.
But it is the object-field of that mind.
This is called the establishment of the distinction of dharmas without form and without obstruction through the five characteristics that are contrary to the above.
Next, the distinction of contaminated dharmas is established through five characteristics.
What are the five?
Namely, by means of the matter,
by means of the latent tendencies,ğŸ”½by means of association,
by means of the object-field,
and by means of arising.
What is the matter of contaminated dharmas?
Namely, pure internal form,
and external form that is dependent and independent on it.
If the defiled mind and mental factors,
or the wholesome, indeterminate mind and mental factors, etc.,
this contaminated matter,
according to what is appropriate, is said to be contaminated by the remaining four characteristics.
Namely, by means of the latent tendencies,ğŸ”½by means of association,
by means of the object-field,
and by means of arising.
If, regarding the pure forms,
And in all the minds and mental factors mentioned above,
the seeds of afflictions have not yet been destroyed or eliminated.
They are called latent tendencies and also called coarseness.
If they have not yet been completely eliminated,
it should be known that all [minds and mental factors] are called contaminated because of the latent tendencies.
If the defiled minds and mental factors
are called contaminated because of association.
If there are things,
if they are the domain of direct perception,
if they are produced by contamination and arise from the dominant condition,
in this way, all [things] are called contaminated because they are the objects of contamination.
Here, the present is called having things.
The past and future are called not having things.
If it is the domain of the consciousness of pure form, it is called the domain of direct perception.
If it is the domain of the other [types of consciousness], it should be known as not the domain of direct perception.
All the external sense bases that arise from the dominant condition of the internal sense bases
are called produced by contamination and arisen from the dominant condition.
Only their objects should be known as contaminated.
Why is this?
If one gives rise to various afflictions by taking the past and future as objects,
since past and future are not real things,
one is not said to be defiled by taking them as objects.
If present things are not the objects of direct perception,
such as pure form and all defiled wholesome and indeterminate minds and mental factors,
they are also not the objects of afflictions.
They are said to be defiled.
But only by giving rise to various afflictions due to the arising of images produced by one's own discrimination,ğŸ”½those dharmas
are not the objects of that clear understanding.
As for being defiled by arising,
it means that because the latent afflictions have not been permanently eliminated,
the objects that accord with the afflictions appear before one,
and one engages in improper attention to them.
For these reasons, all dharmas that are presently arising, have already arisen, or will arise in the future,
in this way, all are said to be defiled by arising.
Moreover, all unwholesome karmic retributions and the external things that are produced by the dominant power of karmic retributions are also produced.
Therefore, they are called contaminated.
Moreover, all the afflictions that bind the wholesome and unwholesome realms are produced.
The things that are produced by them are also called contaminated.
These are called the five aspects by which the distinction of contaminated dharmas is established.
Namely, by reason of things,ğŸ”½by reason of latent tendencies,
by reason of association,ğŸ”½by reason of objects,
and by reason of production.
Next, the distinction of uncontaminated dharmas is established by five aspects.
What are the five?
First, there are dharmas that are called uncontaminated because they are free from the entanglements.
Namely, all wholesome and indeterminate minds and mental factors, their bases and objects, and form,
as well as wholesome and indeterminate minds and mental factors.
Second, there are dharmas that are called uncontaminated because the latent tendencies are severed.
That is, all wholesome dharmas that have already been permanently eliminated by the elimination of the afflictions to be eliminated by the path of seeing and cultivation,
and part of the indeterminate form, all indeterminate dharmas, and all wholesome worldly mind and mental factors.
The dharmas of the three realms are called uncontaminated because they are eliminated and extinguished.
That is, all defiled mind and mental factors are called uncontaminated because they do not arise.
Because they do not arise, nirvana is revealed.
This nirvana is called uncontaminated.
Fourth, there are dharmas that are eliminated by the path of seeing. Because they are the antidote to elimination,
and because their nature is liberated,
they are called uncontaminated.
That is, all the path of seeing.
Fifth, there are dharmas that are eliminated by the path of cultivation. Because they are the antidote to elimination,
and because their nature and continuity are liberated,
that is, all the supramundane path of cultivation and the path of no-more-learning.
It should be known that these are the five aspects by which the distinction of uncontaminated dharmas is established.
Next, the distinction of contaminated dharmas is established by five aspects.
What are the five?ğŸ”½Namely, due to the matter,
due to the causes and conditions,
due to the intrinsic nature,
due to the companions,
and due to the arising.
Among them, the five appropriated aggregates are called the matter of the dharmas with disputes.
If one is tainted by the enjoyment of love and attachment,
it is called the cause and condition of disputes.
If it is the nature of impermanence, the nature of suffering, and the nature of change,
it is called the intrinsic nature of disputes with disputes.
The ignorance and foolishness regarding these disputes
are called the companions of disputes.
Due to these causes and conditions, the five dark categories arise,
which is called the arising, namely the disputes, contradictions,
and the desires and views that give rise to attachment.
Or other types,
are the first dark category.
If there is no shame or remorse for any of the afflictions and entanglements,
and one often abides in that nature,
it is the second dark category.
If there are Å›ramaá¹‡as or brÄhmaá¹‡as
who go against the right path,

Next, due to contemplating the objects, as it is said:
The name overshadows all, there is no name that surpasses it.

As for revealing the selflessness of dharmas,
it means skillfully understanding the nature of the imagined,
and skillfully understanding conventional names and words.
It can eliminate all the characteristics that are the basis for those [imagined natures].
Therefore, it is said to be able to outshine everything.
If one goes beyond these four formless aggregates,
the characteristics and entities of the self are definitely unobtainable.
If one goes beyond conventional names and words,
the characteristics and entities of the imagined nature are also unobtainable.
If one does not skillfully understand these two,
then one will be attached to all the characteristics of one's own realm,
and the arising and turning of all defiled characteristics,
and all defilements arise due to the power of those [imagined natures].
Moreover, the Buddha, the World-Honored One, spoke these words with this hidden meaning:
Because of grasping the self-nature of dharmas, one grasps the nature of the self and turns [toward it].
